definition: scholars tend to disparage one another (idiom)
language/culture/writing/formal/literary/gentle/(old) classifier for coins/Kangxi radical 67
surname Wen
man/person/people/CL:個|个[ge4],位[wei4]
each other/one another/mutually/fret on the neck of a pipa 琵琶[pi2 pa5] (a fret on the soundboard is called a 品[pin3])
surname Xiang
appearance/portrait/picture/government minister/(physics) phase/(literary) to appraise (esp. by scrutinizing physical features)/to read sb's fortune (by physiognomy, palmistry etc)
light/easy/gentle/soft/reckless/unimportant/frivolous/small in number/unstressed/neutral/to disparage

sentences.english: The phenomenon men of letters tend to despise one another of srpeaded invisibly.
sentences.chinese: 无形之中使文人相轻的现象蔓延了。

sentences.english: The fact that most men of letters despise each other may result from their jealousy.
sentences.chinese: 文人相轻很可能源自于文人之间的互相嫉妒。

sentences.english: I considered that of all ages literati despised each other.
sentences.chinese: 认为是文人相轻自古皆然的事。

scholar/literati

(literary) hypocrite/two-faced person

definition: to despise/to scorn
sectarian bias/parochialism

to think highly of oneself (idiom); giving oneself airs/arrogant and self-important

common people/laity (i.e. not priests)

to be narrowly partisan/to unite with those of the same views but alienate those with different views
